None of his cavaliers shall were a lock,
I'll have them all cut off, and every year
Be paid in such a tribute for my wrongs.
As for proud Saxon, say my word is kept,
And bid him warily respect his own:
The French King's palace shall not save his life,
Nor the best rampired bulwark in the land,
Except he answer me as fits a peer.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.l: But to the emperor, what's your will to him?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: That as he run from Spain, he shall run hence,
Or I shall make him a poor emperor.
His bastard bravery tell him must go down,
And the legitimate wear Caesar's crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fail not to utter every syllable
Both of the Palsgrave's sending and our own.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.l: I shall deliver both.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Take't how they please,
If they fly hence, we'll follow through the seas.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: I go. Exit Cullen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: High is this embassy, like to your valour,
Which I admire, and love ardently;
That I could wish your presence all my days,
And think your company to me more sweet
Than mine own kingdom, or my crown besides.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Your love and royal presence I desire.

sp.speaker: K. Clynton,
sp.l: And bold Fitzwaters, be it your charge,
Provided well of our best ships and soldiers,
To sail to Germany, and free our friends,
Kept as we hear there with a slender guard,
In a weak castle.

sp.speaker: Old Fitz.
sp.l: Which we'll soon beats down.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: And bring them hither.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Or return no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: March forwards to the place where we'll encamp

div.stage: Enter Fitzwaters, artoyse, Vandome, and Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: What should the reason be of this dissension
And why is young Fitzwaters froward thus?

sp.speaker: Artoyse.
sp.l: His arguments are strong and forcible.

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.l: Single us hither to the forest side,
Under pretence to plot more privately,
And now not only to mislike! our drifts,
But call us punies, and unskilful men,
If shows a spleenful hatred to us all.

sp.speaker: Y. Frytz.
sp.l: Not unto all, but only to you two:
Why should the Earl and I born a lord's son,
Join with a pair of base companions,
In such a weighty cause as a King's death:
I know you'll say you have been physicians,
Sailer, and soldiers, and in such disguise,
Done some exploit that have deserved respect,
I grant as much, but yet your births are mean.
No gentry in your blood was ever known
By natural heraldry, your low descents
Disables us, and we must seek to rise,
With others of our own condition.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come Vandome, of ourselves we'll do the deed

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: That were the engrossing of the same from us
And so you would have all the thanks yourselves:
Neither commixed with us, nor yet alone,
Shall it be acted, but as we are the best
In birth, and ability to do it,
We'll have the privilege of doing it:

sp.speaker: Vandome.
sp.l: And we should give it over.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: To your betters.
Or having fit place, Artoise and myself,
Will kill you first, then cast you in the river.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: He speaks what we intend.

sp.speaker: Mendozze.
sp.l: Intend your worse?
Caesar has promised him the Palsgrave's place,
And I shall be the marquess Brandenburg:
Think you such titles shall be lost by fear.
Our valour has been tried with worthy men,
And ere we lose the glory of the act,
Vandome and I do mean to use you so.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: They'll ne'er be honest.

sp.speaker: Vandome.
sp.l: Come sir, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Most resolute villains, how they would outbrave us?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: But noble Artoise, now the fire is given
The cannon must go off.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Unto their deaths.
sp.stage: Fight. Y. Fyth and Artoise kill Vandoume, and Mendozza.
sp.l: So they are dead, and now the fame remains
Only to us, that will accomplish it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ftyh.
sp.l: Only to me, that will perform't alone.
Thinks Artoise those were slain cause they are base?
Or that I wrought you to assist my plot,
Because you are of the nobility?
No, I have still this maxim in my thoughts,
That a competitor, though ne'er so noble,
Takes away half the same in every thing:
I could have opened this unto you all,
But that I thought myself too weak for three:
And therefore providently used thy strength,
To kill them first, that I might slay thee after.
Now they are dead, thy life must follow theirs,
And so I share the honour to myself:
I will be Palsgrave, marquess Brandenburg,
And the Bohemian King in me alone,
Caesar shall write himself three friends in one.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: I do not think thou meanst to be a traitor.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: Now you come near me, but that secrets mine,
And seeking it you must dig through my heart,
Or it will ne'er be found, it lies so close.

sp.speaker: Art:
sp.l: I'll know it, or a reason in your blood.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz:
sp.l: Wilt thou turn honest?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Do not torture me,
With repetition of that beggar's name:
Whom none but idiots, innocents, or blocks
Will entertain.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: I would change your mind
From this erroneous and ill boding thought,
Because of late you freed me from the rock,
But if it be so hurtful to your sight
Be your own death, I'll not reveal my mind.

sp.speaker: Arto.
sp.l: If that I cannot force it with my sword,
I'll let it alone.
So lie together, three a pair royal makes,
And here's a pair royal of excellent villains;
These have slain princes by their own confession,
These made a nation swim in her own blood,
The stream is turned with you, 'tis now high flood:
But I must cast you all into the river.
Yea, swords and all, to clear me from suspect;
Suspect? by whom this place yields no such eye,
'Tis well the worlds rid of their villainy. Exit.

div.stage: Enter severally, the French King and Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.l: His highness here, than Floramell give back.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: 'Tis she, a word; there's no retiring hence.
In vain you strive, my force opposed against yours,
Will easily subdue your woman's strength,
But there's a power included in your eye
That conquers Kings, subdues a deity.
And he that had the strength to rule those graces,
Might ne'er be caught, yet view the brightest faces:
One kiss, and I'll no more importune you.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: On that condition, I will grant you one.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: But you must give it me.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Dian forbid, that were immodesty.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: It must be so.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.l: Upon your kingly oath,
Never hereafter to renew your suit.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Now by my crown I swear.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: 'Tis done:
And with this kiss, a second fire begun,
More ardent are my thoughts now then before:
I loved thee well, but now I love thee more.
Thou shalt not leave me, but for ever dwell,
Where I abide, thy absence is my hell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Think on your oath.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: At lover's perjury, the gods themselves do wink.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A King say so, pardon me sir, your will I'll not obey.
But your oath broken mainly run a away. Exit Floram.

div.stage: Enter the Queen, having heard their conference.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: So, so, so: this is the affection that you bear to me?
Thinks the French King I'll not revenge this wrong?
As I am Queen of France, I'll make her know,
What 'tis to be corrival in my love:
She dies by heaven.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: If thou but spoil a hair,
Or shed one drop of her celestial blood
For any courtesy I have offered her,
My wrath shall: as a fury haunt the deed.
And I'll torment thee for such cruelty,
Worse than the damned in the world below.
I seldom threaten, but I do it straight,
Her death thy hell, look to't, 'tis a shrewd fate.

sp.speaker: F. Queen.
sp.l: He ever yet was sovereign of his word,
What shall I do, brook this corrivalship?
No, since I cannot in the realm of France,
Have the revenge my longing heart desires,
Elsewhere I'll seek it, I of late behold
An English lord in favour at the court,
His name Fitzwaters, and I love him well:
By his procurement I will lay a plot,
To yield King John unto his enemies,
So to obtain my purpose, if it take
However fools may think to project ill,
It likes me well, because I have my will.

div.stage: Enter a Frenchman and an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: An Englishman and a traveller; what are you?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: A Frenchman, and no traveller.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Then give way; for I am the better man.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: The better man?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Ay, the better man, by the perambulation of 2. or 3. thousand miles, I have seen the great Turk borrow money, and never mind the repayment on't.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Peuh, is that all? we have a number of great Christians that will do so, and when a man comes to demand his own somewhat boldly, he shall be committed to prison, or made a fool, to stand waiting at the foredoor where the coach stands, whiles the lord steals out at the backdoor by water.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: That our tradesmen can tell, to their great hindrance, and I myself know this, that being in poverty, a lord called me by my name thrice, but he would not remember it once, when he came to his lands.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p: The reason is, lest thou shouldst beg some of his new-living.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Nay rather for fear of paying the old score.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Sure thou art some nobleman's bastard, thou canst tell their tricks so right.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: And by some great woman: for I can tell you their tricks too.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: Your only fine lady is wantonness, and new fashions, your citizen's wife gallops after. But she is not so well horsed to overtake her.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Now we are in the discourse of women, what countrywomen dost thou love best?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: I love none.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: I love all, and to kiss them after the fashion of all nations.

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: Why I pray sir, do not all nations kiss alike?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: You are no traveller, and therefore I'll bear with your ignorance: but know this, your Spaniard, as he is proud, he kisses proudly, as if he scorned the touch of a lady's lip; marry you Frenchmen draw it in, as if he would swallow her alive: now the Italian has soon done with the upper parts, to be tickling of the lower: and we Englishmen can never take enough at both ends.

sp.speaker: Frenchm:
sp.p: Is not your name master do much?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: It is, and yours (I think should be monsieur do little.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: We ere somewhat a kin in the first part of our names, and I pray heartily let us be better acquainted together.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: You must do as I do then, and since we were both appointed, to wait here for the French Queens coming, let's take her gold, and forswear ourselves.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Here comes her majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Are you resolved to undergo this charge? 'tis but an oath, which I will guild with crowns,
and bear you out against the law.

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: I can do little being so animated, if I should not forswear myself, for so fair a Queen.

sp.speaker: Englishm:
sp.p: And I'll do as much as your majesty will have me do.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Take this in earnest, and when 'tis done, you shall have more.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p: And from this time forwards, let us be forsworn brothers.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.l: Content. Exeunt French. And English.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I'll instruct you: here comes Fitzwaters.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: According to your majesty's command,
I come to know your pleasure for the letter
I should deliver to the English King,
With that base strumpet that has injured you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: There is the letter, which I charge you bear unto King Edward, and assure his grace I will perform what I have promised in't, I'll send the strumpet to you instantly. Exit Queen.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: I know not by what influence I am fallen
Into the affection of this potent Queen:
But she has sworn she loves me as her soul:
And to enjoy me in her amorous bed,
Would spend the revenues of the crown of France
Were it her own: I'll temporize with her,
To effect some plot upon my sovereign's foes,
But she shall know, although she love me well,
My heart's desires were drowned with Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: By all descriptions this should be the man,
To whom I am directed by the Queen;
But whom do I behold the young Fitzwaters?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: 'Tis she, o no, she's in the ocean drowned,
No; she escaped it seems as well as I.
But I will take no acquaintance of my love,
Till she has cleared her from the Queen's suspect.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: It is not meet I take acquaintance first,
Nor will I till I know a just cause why,
Of his familiar dealings with the Queen,
Here is the key her highness promised you.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: And you the prisoner to be safe locked up,
For your incontinence and wanton life.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: You do me wrong, I hate incontinence,
Nor did I ever love a wanton life:
I am a desolate lady, shipwrecked here,
And had a husband once, too like thy looks,
But not of such a rude condition.
O were he present, and should hear thee speak
Such boisterous terms against his honoured wife,
He would out of the virtue of his mind
Knowing my conversation to be good,
Write this base slander in thy villain's blood.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: So confident, her innocence is great,
That can do this sincerely without tricks:
But if you be the same that you would seem,
How comes that your reputations grown,
Into such scandal, and your name the theme,
Of every idle fellow in the court?
That grooms report, fair infortunate is:
The French Kings love; nay worse his concubine.
The voice of men is held the voice of God:
And where an evil is so far proclaimed,
The generality approves the guilt,
And she's unworthy to survive a minute,
To be the separation of two hearts,
Made one by marriage.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: Kill me, kill me then.
Having my sentence, wherefore am I spared?
Or do you take delight to torture me?
Before you serve the execution
The law requires no more but death for lust.
The lingering is a note of tyranny.
It is sufficient that the wretch must die,
The sooner done, the lesser cruelty.
But if your conscience urge you to forbear,
I shall confute your worthless arguments,
And tell you in the pureness of my soul,
Report's a liar, common talk a fool.
Waiters and grooms, lightheaded like their plumes,
And those that do attend in princes' courts,
Too active and quick-witted to deprave
A courting they proclaim for a consent,
A favour for the deed, believe them not:
It is too common, this they hourly do,
And think none chaste, but her whom none did woo,

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: But you did kiss the King.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: The Queen did see it,
Urged by constraint, and kingly violence.
Upon condition he should woo no more:
And for that kiss I am esteemed a whore:
If you believe I am, I pray proceed,
I kissed the King, do you a murderous deed.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: Rise, rise, hereafter the discourse I'll tell,
Mean time Fitzwaters welcomes Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: So then I am honest by your own confession,
But ere I entertain you as a husband,
I'll be resolved what love has passed between
The Queen and you, that you her agent are,
In such a weighty cause as is my life.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: Runs the stream this way, is the wind turned thus?

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: I must know all.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: In sight of heaven I vow
She is as chaste for any lust from me,
As unborn infants, and I use her love,
But to advance my sovereign and his realm.
No other case by honour I protest,
In sign whereof I oppose an innocent breast
Against the sword: if you believe not, kill,
But never man died for a lesser ill.

sp.speaker: Floramel.
sp.l: I am satisfied, rise love, and let us go,
There's no true joy without some taste of woe.

div.stage: Enter French King, bastard, Saxon, Trier, and Mentz, Queen.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Prosperity I think was born in France,
'Tis so obsequious unto all our act;
And like a subject waits upon our will:
Tomorrow is this happy interview,
In which Fitzwaters and the Earl of Artoise,
Have promised to surprise the English King,
And the ambitious Palsgrave.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: If it take,
We shall have cause to praise our happiness.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Take, out of all surmise: and in my thoughts
It is as good already as performed.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: I think no less.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: It is most probable.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.l: Where is the Queen she promised us a mask?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: The 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.l: Be jovial Caesar: mirth began the night:
And we will end it with the like delight.

div.stage: Enter King Edward, the Palsgrave and Y. Fitz, Floramell, Cullen, and divers lords in the mask, they dance there.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: We are beholding to you gentlemen,
For this your courtship, pray discover now.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: We will, and make you all die prisoners.

sp.speaker: F.k.
sp.l: King Edward here?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: The Palsgrave.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: All our foes.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Whose plot was this?

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: Or is it not a dream?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: 'Tis such a dream you'll never waken from?
To talk of this strange admiration,
Which like the night hovers on every eye:
Know that I have deluded you with hopes
Vain, like those villains, which my sword did kill,
And by a letter to the King delivered,
Sent by your Queen, to be revenged for lust,
I caused his majesty to enter thus.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I received them in at the back gate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's the lady that has wronged the Queen?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.l: Here is my troth-plight wife,
Freer from that soul imputation,
Then is her majesty from jealousy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is she then chaste?

sp.speaker: French King:
sp.l: I'll answer for the virgin,
By my good fortunes once, now by my beard,
She is as nobly virtuous of a stranger,
As ere I knew, and though I sought her love,
I ne'er obtained it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, where is my witness?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Son, call them in.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: What can you swear?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: What must he swear?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: I'll swear that the lady is a good lady,
The Queen a good Queen, there's an end of swearing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: And more than you should get of me, but that the Queen gave us gold to say something: but who have we here sirrah?

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: Players, by this light players: o I love a play with all my heart.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.l: Begin, begin, we are set.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: That's a brave King.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: That's a brave boy that plays the Queen's part.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: He shall be my juggler.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: And when the play's done, I'll be at charges
To bid them all to supper.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: Would I were a-bed ,

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: I'll lead you thither.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.l: God a mercy good Chamberlain.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: The play's done, and now we must go home. Farewell. Exeunt fools.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But shall the stream turn, this way is my plot
Become so weak? you will believe a subject
Before a Queen? I have outshot myself,
In seeking justice at an enemy's hand:
This is a cross beyond the strength of brain;
Sure I shall end my days in lunacy,
Like one to whom due vengeance is denied,
Because of weakness, on myself I'll turn
The fury that should light upon my foe,
Scatter my hair, like chaff before the wind,
Hell in this world dwells in a jealous mind,Exit. Q.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Our revelling has struck day out of night,
And bright Aurora ushers forth the sun
To his diurnal course; yet neither night,
Day, nor the morning, with her flaring beams,
Can stir up valour in this Saxons breast:
What, is thy mind made captive with thy body?
Or thinkst thou that I take advantages
Where honour should be showed, I'm still myself
Ready to give an answer to thy challenge
As at the first, and if thou conquerst me,
By my achievements I will set thee free.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: You show yourself in this a noble foe,
And I receive more honour than I hoped:
I thought, because I was your prisoner,
You had esteemed captivity a conquest.
But since you have awaked sleeping valour,
And given your captive such a privilege?
I am the same bold combatant to dare,
And do as as erst I did intend.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.p: Choose your own weapons, and I'll meet you straight.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: My armour there. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: Clinton and bold Fitzwaters are arrived,
And bring with them released from servitude
Brandenburg, Savoy, and Bohemia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Guide them in.

div.stage: Enter old Fytzwaters, Clinton, Drum, and Cullens with Savoy, Brandenberg, and Bishops, with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Old fitzwater
sp.p: Those with ourselves, we humbly do present unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Such as our swords by a glorious victory set free.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: When heaven is pleased to give prosperity, how it flows in ● welcome my honoured friends: I am glad your thraldoms prove your liberty.

sp.speaker: Savoy.
sp.l: The King of England has been always kind.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I have ever found it so.

sp.speaker: Brandenb:
sp.l: And so have I.

sp.speaker: Old fitzwater
sp.p: Whom do I fee? my son that stole my bride? As you respect my service (Gracious King) let me have justice.

sp.speaker: Clint:
sp.l: Clinton kneels with him.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: To their great service, greater I oppose,
And do beseech your highness wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Old-fyztw:
sp.l: Wrong thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.p: I wrong me, may not Kings do wrong? Or dare you think because you are my father, I'll lose my wife.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: Daughter come from him, lest I force you hither.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: Father I may not.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: Fathers both she shall not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We'll hear no more of these bold menaces
On pain of death I charge you both forbear:
And let my censure sway this difference.
In England as your house the Bishop told me
That Clinton's daughter by a precontract,
Was young Fitzwaters wife, and that some trick
Betwixt the fathers to preserve their wealth,
Broke off the match, to have him wed the old.
This being true; I charge you on your lives
Urge him no further in his lawful choice,
But as 'twas wrong enough to hinder it,
Make him amends, by being reconciled,

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw.
sp.l: Which I entreat upon a dutious knee.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Old fitzwater
sp.l: Rise, rise, I am friends with you both, and
When my anger's over you shall find me a kind father.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: So shall you.

sp.speaker: Y. fytz.
sp.l: All let's are now removed, I am truly happy.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: The combatants are ready.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Guide them in.

div.stage: Enter severally Saxon and the Palsgrave armed, and in their shyrts, drum and culiors.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Idle are words where we must use our swords,
Yet that it may appear what minds we bear,
Now we are marched into this dreadful lists,
Know that this day my honour shall exceed.
Or I lie breathless where I set my foot.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Were thy breast marble, and thy ribs of brass,
Saxon will have the superiority,
Or in this dreadful place, his life expires.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: Sound trumpets, and the destinies guide all.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: The Palsgrave is invincible I think.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Not to be overcome.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Nor to be tamed by any.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Matchless, and far beyond the praise of words, are all thy actions, let me honour thee.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: Our friends returned in safety cheers more

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Caesar resign your title unto savoy, and Savoy, fit you up, whilst the doctors hear join all their hands to make thee emperor.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: 〈◊〉 as the first.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: And to get your love,
We will disgrace ourselves to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Receive the crown, but as he wear the same may it crush out his brains.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Long live and happily the 〈◊〉 Caesar.

sp.speaker: Savoy.
sp.l: As happily as your kinded love's have made me.
And long as please the heavens.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: Your fare●●● rights 〈◊〉 perfect ●● with state in Germany, whither I make the majesty of England, and all our friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'll bear you company.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Fair winds and prosperous ●● our several
Realms, we wish and pray for, 'tis not our least good
To be the favourites of the waning flood.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
